State Representative Heather Edelson
June 19 at 9:51 PM ·

Last Summer my office convened a Summer Policy Working Group of bright youth from Edina, Lakeville and surrounding areas.

This group of young leaders found that our Minnesota schools did not consistently teach about the harms of vaping in middle school. We drafted a bill and worked with educators, Principals and Superintedent’s to ensure this could be improved and aimed at education as prevention.

The students met with the revisor’s office, surveyed health teachers across MN, made compromises on language and we ensured the bill was bipartisan with Senator Carla Nelson as the chief author in the Senate. Senator Nelson and I have both long been advocates on protecting youth from the harms of nicotine addiction.

I am beyond proud to report our bill passed the MN House and Senate this evening during our Special Session and will be headed to the Governor’s desk to become law!

Well done to all the students for your tireless work and a huge shout out to @Arjun Maheshwari our Edina student lead for his hard work! #YouthLeaders

When it was announced that students would engage in distance learning for the remainder of the school year, the opportunity to participate in a May Term project was no longer an option. With this in mind, seniors Sydney Piere and Jack Piere proposed an alternative to this year-end project. Their idea was to have their classmates work in teams to create proposed solutions for future problems that might arise should distance learning continue. From that suggestion, the Class of 2020 - Big Idea Project was formed.

The Big Idea Project gave seniors this challenge: to brainstorm creative solutions for how EHS could maintain academic rigor, student support and wellness, relationships between students and with teachers, and promote staff wellness, in light of social distancing and distance learning.

Another amazing accomplishment today as 700 items were delivered to students so they can fully engage in Distance Learning! A variety of academic material, technology devices, hotspots, special education materials and devices, and some musical instruments were packaged and loaded by paras and volunteers onto 14 EPS school buses and vans for delivery. Paras rode each bus, ran items to the door and rang the bell. Observing social distancing guidelines, they stepped back and waited to be sure the items were picked up. Lots of logistical planning by Teaching & Learning, DMTS, Special Education, teachers and principals. Hats off to Transportation who created and drove the bus routes for these special deliveries. If you are still expecting materials, there are more special deliveries scheduled for tomorrow!

Last week, the Edina Education Fund presented education grants to the selected recipients in two main focus areas: literacy, and mental health and wellness.

With the $3,500 towards literacy: Creek Valley will pilot a new audio book program; there will be more multilingual library books available at Valley View's media center; and the Early Learning Center will be supported as they implement a new literacy read-aloud library program.

With the $6,500 granted to mental health and wellness: financial assistance will be provided districtwide for families to access school-based mental health counseling; and Creek Valley's fourth graders will pilot a "Learning Through Movement" program, which will provide a space for movement while learning and reviewing academic concepts. Both Creek Valley pilot programs will be evaluated for potential expansion to all elementary schools.

Learn more about the Edina Education Fund and how they support educational efforts around the district: https://www.edinaedfund.org/s/

“It’s cool to walk away knowing you saved 3 lives,” said senior Bennett . “It’s really easy to do and anyone who can do it should do it.”
